dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bare as all hell. The trees stripped of their bark and wh like ghosts. Some torn violently from their roots and fel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STARK GRAY SUNLIGHT shafts between the trees, clouded by creeping fog that obscures the true color of everything. LIGHT SNOW flutters. The world monochrome, lifeless and c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CAT prowls across the dead earth. Barely recognizable a the domestic breed it might once have been. Its fur mangy rank, body rib-thin from starvation. Entirely feral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It moves slowly, cautiously. Sniffing the air, scanning t forest, alert. Trusting nothing of its surroundings. It p across a leaf-strewn clearing, closing stealthily on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DEAD MAN, splayed face-down in the earth. His feet bare Face frozen in a grim death mask. A GAPING GUNSHOT WOUND his head, the dried blood caked around it matting his hai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the cat moves closer, approaching warily:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About thirty yards away. Someone is watching. Waiting. SL DEEP BREATHS, heard through a GASMASK RESPIRATOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MIRRORED LENSES reflecting the forest clearing, locke onto the cat. The slow, metered breathing continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAT slows, but continues pacing toward the corpse. Mo cautious than ever. It inches forward, sniffing at the bo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE WATCHER. Crouched behind the mangled stump of a fe tree. Concealed beneath a camouflaging mesh of leaves, tw and bracken. A "ghillie suit" of the kind used by snipers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAT sniffs at the dead man's hand, frozen by death in grotesquely contorted claw. The animal still unsure. Look around again, checking its surroundings for predators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE WATCHER moves almost imperceptibly. The leaves coveri him rustle ever so slightly as we hear - just barely - th familiar creaking sound of a BOW STRING BEING DRAWN TAUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAT hears it. Looks up, alert. Staring right at the watcher, but he is too well camouflaged to be seen. An interminable, tense BEAT - is the prey going to flee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, the cat turns its attention back to the carcass, nibbling gingerly at the flesh of the man's fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE WATCHER looses the arrow. It sails across the clearin and SKEWERS THE CAT clean through. It drops to the ground

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE WATCHER STANDS, shaking off the ghillie suit, reveali him to us for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wears a weather-beaten knee-length duster. Hooded swea with more layers beneath that. Torn pants and scuffed wor boots. Everything filthy and battered from years of wear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Along with the goggles, his face remains obscured by a DISPOSABLE PAPER DUST MASK and a CRUDELY-FASHIONED FUR HA with dangling ear flaps that may once itself have been a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around his neck he wears a silver SAINT CHRISTOPHER PENDA hanging from a frayed twine cord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name is ELI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shoulders the bow and walks across the clearing. Crouc beside the dead cat and pulls out the arrow. Wipes the bl from the shaft, then reaches down to collect the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the cat SCREECHES AND FLAILS WILDLY! Eli recoils falling backward, stunned, as the cat - MORTALLY WOUNDED FIGHTING TO THE DEATH - bites and claws desperately at hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli struggles violently with the cat, wrestling it to the ground and grabbing up a HUNK OF FALLEN BRANCH. He holds writhing animal down and CLUBS IT until it lays still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits back, breathing harder than the dustmask will all He yanks it down, revealing the dirty, unshaven face bene Impossible to tell his age, but certainly not a young man

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment he just sits there. Then bundles up the dead and returns to the mangled tree stump. Folds away his ghi suit into a nearby RUCKSACK which he hauls up onto his ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A canteen dangles from the backpack, a SHOTGUN strapped t its side. Eli reaches down for his final possession - an SAMURAI SWORD in a scabbard which he slings across his ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gazes up at the sky. A snowflake drifts down and lands his cheek. He reaches up and brushes it away, leaving a B SMEAR on his face. Not snow after all, but some kind of A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli emerges from the treeline onto the cracked and ruptur asphalt. Lined by more of those ghostly, stripped-bare tr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sniffs the air, breathing it in. Checks the road in bo directions. Deserted. A few yards away is the rusted, bur out chassis of a CAR. He heads toward it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car rests half on the road, half in the adjacent ditc Stripped of its tires and engine. In the driver's seat is MUMMIFIED BODY. A BULLET HOLE piercing its forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli regards the body dispassionately. Tries the door hand but it's jammed. He yanks on it harder and eventually wrenches it open. He leans in and checks the man's feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're bare. No shoes or socks. Eli curses under his bre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves the car behind and heads on down the road. As h walks away, we see that the sole of one of his boots has loose, held in place now only by a rubber band.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli continues down the road. He ambles along slowly, a ma no hurry. A man who has been walking a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road has since emerged from the forest. Passing now through a wasteland of dead scrub brush and urban junk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun beats down from directly overhead. The sky has no color to it, paper-white. The unfiltered sun's stark ligh leaves everything seeming bleached-out, over-exposed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRANE UP as Eli walks on. On the horizon is the silhouett a CITY. Or what was once a city. Columns of BLACK SMOKE r from within, casting a deathly pall over the skyline. BUR AND BROKEN SKYSCRAPERS jut out like tombstones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli reaches a fork in the road and stops. The road he's o appears to wind off in the direction of the ruined city o the horizon. The other fork continues on into the wastela

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a brief pause, Eli changes direction and heads off the other fork, away from the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little more than a main street lined with storefronts. El walks steadily along, side-stepping rubble and debris. Ignoring the petrified corpses lying in the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He passes by abandoned stores, every one picked clean. Em shelves, smashed windows. Looted and burned. He doesn't e look inside, knowing already that he will find nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until he comes to a store that does cause him to stop. An fashioned sign squeaks on rusted hinges in the breeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps into the doorway and pushes open the door. It sw open on its one remaining hinge before splintering away f the frame and crashing to the floor in a cloud of dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli steps inside. Like all the others, the store has been cleaned out. Shoe racks and empty boxes strewn over the floor. The whole place reeking of dead, musty air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli looks around, just to be sure. Drags his sheathed swo idly along the empty racks as he checks them. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he turns back for the door, his foot nudges against a box. It's not empty. He crouches down, flips the lid off hopefully... and pulls out a LADY'S HIGH-HEELED SHOE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strokes the shoe leather with his hand. Shakes his hea grimly, then tosses the shoe back into the box and leaves

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the outskirts of town. In disrepair - peeling paint, broken windows, damp-stained walls - but habitable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli stands in the front yard, surrounded by brownish, overgrown weeds. Thinking it over. Turns to face the sett sun. It will be dark soon. He turns back toward the house

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door is sent CRASHING OPEN with a hard kick, revealing Eli silhouetted in the fading sunlight. The sho unhitched from his pack and held ready. He moves inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another dead place. Flies buzzing in the still, dank air. Everything covered in a thick layer of dust but otherwise largely preserved. An eerie snapshot of a world long gone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every cupboard empty. Eli checks each one, poking around the dark corners with his sword, but finds nothing but du

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the freezer, checks inside. Empty save for a sma ICEBOX. The lid stuck fast with mildew and gunk. Eli digs it with his grimy fingernails and manages to pry it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside are the wizened, petrified remains of a HUMAN HAND Floating in slimy, discolored water. The smell vile and t enough to make Eli retch. He quickly jams the lid back on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wooden bedframe stripped clean. The dresser drawers hav been emptied and lie strewn across the floor. Eli moves toward a large walk-in closet and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No clothes inside - just the near-fossilized corpse of a HANGING BY A NOOSE. Twisting gently back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfazed, Eli crouches down and checks the man's feet. An pair of Converse All-Stars hang limp from the man's skele ankles. Eli calmly sets about unlacing them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He checks the size; they're a fit. He upturns each shoe a shakes the old flakes of mummified flesh from them. Disca his ruined boots and puts on the sneakers, laces them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks around, pacing up and down, getting a feel for t new shoes. They feel good. For the first time, he smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli sits in the corner, roasting the carcass of the dead over a small CAMPFIRE. He cleans the animal's pelts as he watches it cook. Pokes at the meat with a pen-knife, chec it for done-ness. It appears ready to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He clasps his hands together in prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Lord, thank you for your generosity in providing us today with this bountiful feast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He speaks QUIETLY, his voice barely above a whisper. Even we catch the accent - a RASPY, OLD-WORLD MIDWEST DRAWL, l John Wayne or some other long-forgotten western icon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for the many gifts that you have given me. Thank you for your protection and your guidance. Thank you for bringing me this far. I know my long journey's end is near. I ask now only for the strength and the courage to complete the task that you in your infinite wisdom saw fit to bestow upon me over all men. I won't let you down. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He signs a cross over himself, then uses the knife to saw a chunk of meat. Takes a bite, savoring the taste with gr relish. To him, it's grade-A filet mignon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. You hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It appears as though he is talking to himself... until a emerges from his coat pocket, whiskers twitching keenly. offers it some meat. The rat gnaws enthusiastically at it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last of the waning sunlight shafts through the bedroo broken window. Eli rummages through his backpack, pulls o SMALL PACKAGE wrapped in cloth and tied fast with string.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits back in his corner and carefully unwraps it. It's OLD LEATHER-BOUND BOOK. The binding cracked and pages dog eared, thumbed through a thousand times and more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli gazes lovingly at it. Lets his fingers play across th beat-up old leather cover. A cherished thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins to read, half-hidden in the shadows of the fadi sunlight. Silently mouthing the words as he reads them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli closes the book and parcels it back up as before. Replaces it in his pack, then reaches in for something el

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CAR BATTERY. Old and streaked with acid stains. Attache a tangled bunch of ELECTRICAL WIRING and JUMPER CABLES. E reaches into his pocket and produces:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN IPOD. Badly beat-up, the case pretty much held togethe with duct tape. But functional. Eli attaches the battery cable to the iPod and places the headphones in his ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music plays. Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 20 in D Mino Eli rests back against the wall and pushes the volume way

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE MUSIC SWELLS. Eli's fingers dance and swoop in the ai as though conducting an orchestra, as he is transported b the music to another world, a world far from this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunlight shafts through the window. Eli sits slumped in t exact same position, headphones still in his ears. Asleep

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rat scurries up Eli's chest and licks his face. Slowl he wakes, realizing he fell asleep with his music still o Checks the battery. It's dead, drained overnight. He frow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets to his feet, moves to the window and checks outsi All seems quiet. He loads up his backpack and weapons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rat scurries up his leg, onto his duster and disappea into the breast pocket. Eli turns and moves out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gate squeaks shut behind Eli as he exits the front ya

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breathes in the air, turns to feel the warm morning su his face. Then turns away from it and walks on down the r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The landscape barren and featureless, road lined with dea trees. Eli walks along the warped and broken asphalt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road is strewn with burned-out cars and debris from a world long dead. A warped metal sign by the side of the r reads: LITTER REMOVAL NEXT TWO MILES BY: "CIRCUIT CITY".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up ahead is a HUNCHED FIGURE by the side of the road. Eli arrives to see that it's a YOUNG WOMAN. Bone-thin, dresse filthy rags. Skin plagued by an unpleasant rash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SHOPPING CART she was pushing has overturned into a roadside ditch, spilling its contents. Blankets, tins of food, old clothes. She's on her knees trying to gather it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up as she sees Eli approaching. Instantly cower from him, raising her hands to protect herself. Terrified

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Please don't hurt me. Here, take anything you want. You want some food? Take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She offers him a can of pet food with a trembling hand. E stands there looking at her. His expression impossible to read behind the mirrored goggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what the last guys said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli bends down and picks up a couple of the cart's spille contents. Steps forward and offers them to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She blinks. Unsure. Cautiously she reaches out and takes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you help me? The wheel came off. I can't fix it. Maybe if I could get it out of the ditch. But I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli looks at the cart. It has come to rest in the ditch j inches from a THICK BRACKEN HEDGEROW that lines the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks again at the girl. Her faded blouse is unbuttone revealing a little cleavage. Her skirt torn along the leg showing more than a little thigh. Almost deliberate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sniffs the air. Watches the hedgerow warily. Just like cat he hunted, his senses heightened and on alert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the hedge, THREE ROADSIDE BANDITS are crouched, waiting to pounce. Each armed with a crude blunt weapon. exchange anxious looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELI sniffs the air again - then backs away from the girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One good thing about no soap any more. You can smell the road agents a mile off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl's face falls as Eli backs up. The three bandits EMERGE FROM THE HEDGEROW, brandishing their weapons. A co of them wear old sunglasses and goggles similar to Eli's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BANDIT LEADER grabs the girl by a fistful of hair as passes, yanking her painfully to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dumb bitch. What did we tell you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes her away, she crumples to the road in a heap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli backs away, but TWO MORE ARMED BANDITS drop from hidi in the trees behind, cutting off his escape, surrounding

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you got there in the pack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's what they all say. How about you take it off real slow and tip it out so's we can take a look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BANDIT #2 notices the shotgun strapped to the pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, it ain't loaded. They never are. Ain't that right, old man? (BEAT) Open the fucking pack or die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bandit leader steps forward aggressively. Now within striking distance of Eli. He grins, teeth filthy and rott

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want us to do it for you? We can get it off real easy after we've hacked your fucking arms off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli remains perfectly calm. And though he speaks with a s even tone, there is something formidable about his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's real important you boys listen to me and understand. The man I work for, you do not want to cross him. See, I'm under his protection. You stand in my way, you stand in his. And he will cut you down with a righteous fury - through me. For I am his faithful instrument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEAT. The bandit leader looks at Eli incredulously... and then LAUGHS. The other bandits laugh along nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you, some kinda preacher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I got news for you, preacher man. Whatever kinda God you reckon yourself to be working for, he left these parts a long time ago. He ain't here to protect your ass. Now take off the pack and set it on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli doesn't move, doesn't say a word. The bandit leader t another step forward and shoves him in the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fucking listening to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you. You lay that hand on me again and you will not get it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other bandits exchange nervous looks. This is not how it's supposed to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I had just about enough of this shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lunges forward, grabs the shoulder strap of Eli's pack

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you blinked, you missed it. But somehow Eli has now dr his sword. A RIVULET OF BLOOD snakes down along the blade drips onto the asphalt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bandit leader's hand is still gripped firmly around Eli's shoulder strap. But it's no longer connected to his arm. SEVERED HAND hangs there from the strap, dripping blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bandit leader staggers backward and raises the bloody stu where his hand once was. Looks at it in shock and horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What... you just... he just cut my fucking hand off! My fucking hand!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli pries the hand loose from the strap and tosses it ont the road as bandit leader's legs give out and he slumps t the asphalt. His eyes dart around, as though confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you standin' around for? Kiss him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he talkin' about, kiss him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in shock. He means "kill him".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tense BEAT. And then the four remaining bandits ATTACK ALL AT ONCE, weapons flailing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli flourishes the sword. A BLUR, TOO FAST TO FOLLOW. But it's clear he is possessed of an inhuman level of skill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is over in moments. The four bandits LAY SLAIN IN THE ROAD, blood pooling out onto the asphalt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bandit leader crawls toward his severed hand, a few y away. Eli steps in and kicks it out of his reach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you you wouldn't be getting that back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bandit leader looks up to see the figure of Eli bearing d on him, silhouetted ominously against the sun. He looks f moment like an avenging angel, something not of this worl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Eli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that, Eli runs him through with his sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to see the young woman slumped in the road, sobb She cowers again as he approaches, certain that she is ne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He WALKS PAST HER. Sheathes his sword, then pulls out the shopping cart from the ditch and rights it. The woman wat incredulously as he gathers up her supplies into the cart

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it and go on your way. And don't fall in with men like these again. No good can come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli says nothing. Walks back to the slain bandits, crouch beside them and begins searching their bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a scarf from around the neck of one. Finds a Zip lighter on another, checks that it works and pockets it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The five bodies are lined neatly in the ditch, half-cover with dirt. The best burial they are going to get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli stands before them, head bowed in prayer. He speaks quietly and quickly, a speech he has given many times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, the father of mercies, through the death and resurrection of his son has reconciled the world to himself and sent the holy spirit among us for the forgiveness of sins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young woman stands a few yards away, watching him, transfixed. She has never seen anyone like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the ministry of the church may he give you pardon and peace, and I absolve you from your sins in the name of the father, and of the son, and of the holy spirit. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and walks away down the road, passing the woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. You're... a good man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no good men on the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can... can I come with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't even turn back to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks on, into the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straddling the desert like a giant, crumbling monument to long-dead civilization. Eli steadily climbs his way up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes to an abrupt stop as we realize suddenly that th overpass has COLLAPSED at mid-point. RUSTED IRON RODS jut from where the roadway has been severed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli just stands there at the edge for a moment, feeling t wind whip around him, his coat fluttering in the breeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The overpass's collapsed section is now just a MOUNTAINOU PILE OF RUBBLE that leads down to the road below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli steps onto the rubble. About to make his way down whe FREEZES. He hears something. The faintest of sounds. He t cover, peering down at the road beneath the overpass to s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO PEOPLE walking together on the road. We see everythin from ELI'S P.O.V. - too far to make out much detail, but apparently it is a MIDDLE-AGED COUPLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man pushes along an OLD WHEELBARROW covered by a tarp the woman, seemingly his wife, walks alongside. The barro rusted wheel gives out a plaintive, rhythmic SQUEAK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli ducks down again as he hears something else. This tim much louder. The menacing growl of MOTORCYCLE ENGINES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOUR BIKES IN TOTAL. Riding out of the horizon, closing i the couple. They see the bikes coming and panic. Try desperately to steer the barrow off the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bikes screech to a halt and the FOUR RIDERS dismount. Brandishing a variety of weapons. The couple make a run f it but they're quickly chased down and tackled to the gro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman SCREAMS and struggles helplessly as the bikers swarm over the man like a pack of predatory animals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman is pulled to the ground and the clothes strippe from her. Eli turns away. He knows what comes next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli listens as the woman screams and screams. He reaches his shotgun... hesitates... then withdraws his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't your concern. Stay on the path. It ain't your concern. Stay on the path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli repeats it like a mantra. He clearly wants to interve but will not permit himself to. Instead, he simply sits a waits grimly as the woman continues to scream for help. A then finally, suddenly, is silenced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down below, the bodies of the man and woman lay dead and bloodied in the dirt. The bikers tear the tarp from the wheelbarrow, spilling its contents onto the asphalt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ferret through the items, scavenging a few items - w don't see what - and stuffing them into an old cloth satc They leave the rest strewn in the road and ride off in th direction they came, dust pluming in their wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli waits until the sound of the motorcycles has receded the far distance before emerging from his hiding place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli crouches on one knee before the murdered couple. He s a cross over their ravaged bodies as he mutters a prayer under his breath. Then stands and continues on down the r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More desolate wasteland as far as the eye can see. The ro forks again here. Eli arrives at the junction and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road Eli is on leads further into the west. The other fork heads toward a SMALL TOWN just visible on the horizo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HAND-PAINTED SIGN has been driven into the dirt nearby. words, just a series of CRUDE PICTOGRAMS. A BED. A PLATE FOOD. A WATER FAUCET. AN ARROW points toward the town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli pauses, thinking it over. Retrieves the iPod from his pocket. Clicks the button, but no response. He sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and heads down the other fork, toward town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A primitive, sprawling village of tents and barn-like structures. Built from corrugated iron, rotted wood, mold plastic, tarpaulin - materials scavenged from the old wor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HUDDLED RESIDENTS are dressed in little more than rags, m wearing goggles like Eli's to shield their eyes from the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli stands at the edge of town. Reluctant to enter, but h braces himself and walks on in. And as he rounds a corner entering the center of town, an astonishing sight:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The broad thoroughfare now all that remains of whatever t once stood here. Many of the old storefronts still largel intact but patched up with salvaged materials. The asphal street warped and cracked, parking meters bent and smashe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a lot like the abandoned town Eli passed through earlier, except VERY MUCH ALIVE - BUSTLING WITH TOWNSFOLK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's at once a familiar and also a disturbing sight - lik old Norman Rockwell painting of classic small-town Americ but filtered through the devastating eye of an apocalypse unsettling juxtaposition of the old world and the new.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The centerpiece of the town is a GRAND THEATER at the hea the main street. THE PALLADIUM. Like the rest of the town badly damaged and shoddily fixed-up. But still standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli walks down the street and approaches a BLACKSMITH, hammering out a metal plate over an anvil outside his sto

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got an engineer or a fuelman around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blacksmith doesn't look up from his work but motions toward a storefront at the far end of the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli heads down the street. Stopping when he comes across STATUE erected in the center of the road. A TALL MAN crud fashioned in clay. One hand placed paternally on the head a SMALL CHILD, the other outstretched toward the sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he observes the statue, Eli notices that passing resid take a moment to PAUSE AND GENUFLECT before it. Worshippi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curious, Eli reaches up and runs his hand over the statue face. Then hears SHUFFLING FEET behind him and turns as a PARADE OF EMACIATED MEN AND WOMEN trudges past. Roped together at the waist, each man leading the one behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heads shaved, thin from malnutrition. And each one BLIND. They gaze at the ground with pale, dead eyes. They carry picks, shovels and other tools - a sightless CHAIN GANG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli watches as the pathetic parade shuffles past, herded cattle by a brutish CHAIN GANG BOSS who swats at them wit stick to keep them moving and indicate direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, move it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gang boss glares at Eli as he passes by. Eli doesn't return the look, just continues crossing the street as th blind are herded away. Headed toward a wooden building wi pictogram of a LIGHTNING BOLT suspended above the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever this place once was, it's now a kind of POST- APOCALYPTIC RADIO SHACK. Shelves display a variety of goo Engine parts. Old electrical wiring. Small appliances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old ELECTRIC GENERATOR rumbles noisily, powering strin of multi-colored CHRISTMAS LIGHTS that hang all around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the main counter a convoluted Rube Goldberg-esque STILL is running. An ENGINEER in a leather apron pours th remnants of a can of motor oil into the still's funnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attached to the still is an old MOTORCYCLE MIRROR. In its reflection the engineer sees Eli checking out the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without turning around, he reaches surreptitiously behind counter for something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli turns toward the counter - to find the engineer train a PUMP-ACTION SHOTGUN right at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli slowly raises his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not from around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit. Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just a customer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A customer with a shotgun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods toward the shotgun visible on Eli's backpack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You come in here to rip me off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The engineer's hands tremble, his finger tight on the trigger. This man needs to be talked down carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'll set it down. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli nods. Unhitches the pack and sets it down, steps away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You carry a gun in the outland, you don't bring one into town less you live there. Don't you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I forgot. I've been on the road a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This seems to make the engineer more suspicious of Eli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me your hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The engineer jerks the shotgun at Eli nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said show me your fucking hand!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli raises his hand and holds it outstretched, palm faced downward. The engineer watches it closely for any sign of ticks or tremors, but Eli's hand stays steady as a rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sight of the steady hand seems to reassure the engine little. Finally, he lowers the shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just passing through. I need some help. I can pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kinda help? And what kinda pay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to get something out of my pack. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The engineer raises the shotgun nervously again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know. Slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The engineer watches him like a hawk as Eli opens up his and pulls out the car battery. When he sees it, he gasps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli places it on the counter. The engineer looks it over awe, like it's a priceless historical artifact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you find this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Years ago, in the outland back east aways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it just needs a charge. Can you do it? I got the cables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends if you also got the coin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli pulls the Zippo lighter from his pocket. The engineer picks it up, sparks the flint, watches the flame flicker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll take a couple hours. There's a bar across the street you can wait, they just opened up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll wait here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't trust me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (SMILES) I don't know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This once grand theater have been largely gutted - seats out, fixtures and fittings stripped, curtains ripped from stage. But still, there's a sense of grandeur to this pla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking out over the stage, a ROYAL BOX - once the most prestigious seat in the house - has been converted into a OFFICE of sorts. Seats removed and replaced by an ORNATE MAHOGANY DESK facing inward, a CHANDELIER suspended above

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole set-up is gaudy and ostentatious - the work of someone who wants to project an aura of power and wealth, has no taste whatsoever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TALL MAN is seated in a battered leather armchair behin the desk, deeply involved in an OLD PAPERBACK BOOK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The book's cover is faded and partially torn away, the ti still just visible: 7 HABITS OF HIGHLY EFFECTIVE PEOPLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man is OLDER than most we've seen. His skin weathered the elements and by a long life's experience. One of the few people we've seen in this world close to Eli's age - unlike everyone else we've seen, he appears healthy and w groomed. A rich mane of hair, full set of teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wears a tattered SUIT AND TIE. None of it matches, everything scavenged from different outfits and eras. But looks almost civilized. Respectable. His name is CARNEGIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up from his book at the sound of a POLITE COUGH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REDRIDGE stands before him. Tall, powerfully built.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His accent is like caramel. A RICH, DEEP-SOUTH DRAWL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Survey team just finished up their inspection. It ain't good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie lowers his book. Concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How bad is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pressure is down again, and going by the new rod they sank levels're lower than they've ever been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie stands. Thinking. This is bad news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to say. Six months, maybe. A little longer if we're careful. But we're already-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halve the rations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just halved `em last-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So halve them again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEAT. Carnegie stares Redridge down. Nobody but nobody questions his orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to have to say something. Folks were none too happy last time. Gonna be worse now, you can count on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie sighs, rubs his brow. He knows Redridge is right

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LARGE CROWD OF TOWNSFOLK - several hundred strong - has assembled outside the Palladium theater. AN ARMED CREW OF CARNEGIE'S GOONS keeps watch over the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie stands on a BALCONY above the theater marquee. H treats the balcony like a pulpit, speaking through a MICROPHONE connected to an old PA SYSTEM that carries his words to the far reaches of the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you all to remember how far we've come together. And how far we still can go, if only we believe. When I brought us here to this oasis - this promised land - we knew there would be hardships. Knew there would be sacrifices. But we also knew that we were creating for ourselves a world where we could be safe from the horrors of the forsaken lands beyond our borders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd listens intently, hanging on Carnegie's every w He is an incredibly charismatic and persuasive speaker - cultivated image and inspiring, confident delivery remind of a TELEVISION EVANGELIST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I want you all to remember above all that it is not the water with which we have been blessed that is the true lifeblood of this town... but faith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This sends a MURMUR OF DISCONTENT through the crowd. Many don't like where they suspect this may be going. Carnegie senses this and dials up his rhetoric - delivering it now with the fire-brand passion of an old-time baptist preach

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is our faith that sustains us, brothers and sisters! Hallelujah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd is divided. Many return the "Hallelujah" with varying levels of conviction. Others are not convinced. B Carnegie continues unabated, selling it harder than ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And mark me, the ultimate validation of that faith is coming! The sacred Word of Our Lord that formed the world before and will reform it once again is coming to this town to bring it succor, bring it nourishment, bring it new life! For the Almighty Himself has spoken unto me and promised it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie is such an impassioned and inspiring speaker it' almost impossible not to get caught up and swept away by words. His apparently unshakable belief is infectious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the meantime, He has asked us all to be patient. To walk the hard road of the faithful just a little longer. And to do that, we must give just a little more. (BEAT) Water rations will be halved until further notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This sends a much broader ripple of discontent through th crowd - this news has not been received well at all. Some still "keep the faith" but many more are perturbed by thi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie motions for the crowd to settle down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand your frustration. The road to salvation is a difficult one - but what lies at the end of that road is a greater glory, beyond anything you can imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DISCONTENTED VILLAGER steps forward, pushing through th crowd and jabbing his finger angrily up at Carnegie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've heard this all before! When are you going to-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie's goons quickly move in and efficiently SILENCE MAN, removing him from the crowd. Dissent is not tolerate here. Carnegie goes on speaking as if nothing had happene

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know each and every one of you will understand the necessity of this action. It was faith that built this town - and faith that will sustain it even through the dark times that may lie ahead. But it is always darkest before dawn - and the new dawn is coming. (BEAT) May God go with you all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie steps back inside, leaving the crowd to talk amo themselves, clearly mixed about what they have heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the assembled townsfolk disperse, FOUR MOTORCYCLES roa into town and pull up outside the Palladium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the riders dismount, one detaches a CLOTH SATCHEL from bike's cargo rack. The four riders head inside. They each have long, straggly hair and brutish expressions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We recognize them now as the BIKER BANDITS who killed the couple on the road under the freeway overpass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie emerges into the second-floor hallway from the balcony, mopping his brow. Exhausted and stressed from hi grand theatrical display, and from its mixed reception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redridge climbs the stairs to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the road crews just rolled into town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie looks at his cracked old wristwatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course they did, the bar's open. Outlanders, always looking for answers at the bottom of a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not these guys. (BEAT) These guys say they got something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That gets Carnegie's attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get them up here now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was once a grand, gilded entrance foyer has, like th rest of the theater, been largely gutted. But it's still impressive - a spacious bar area with a grand staircase leading up to a second floor, entrance to balcony seats, FADED OLD THEATER POSTERS still hang from the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place has been shabbily converted into a kind of SALO Old ripped-out theater seats arranged around tables. A FIREPLACE sputters dimly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MANGY TABBY CAT walks across the straw-laden floor. A d or so CUSTOMERS in the place, a mixed, rough-looking bunc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redridge emerges from an upstairs room and nods to a grou his MEN who are holding the bikers at the foot of the sta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie checks his reflection in a CRACKED HAND MIRROR, licks his palm and slicks his hair back. He adjusts his t as Redridge's men usher the bikers into his "office".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie wheels around and flashes a smile at them. Just when he gave his balcony address, Carnegie is in performa mode - charismatic and slick like a campaigning politicia

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen! It's truly a delight to see you again! I understand your latest excursion into the outland has been a profitable one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bikers exchange looks. They understood maybe half the words in that sentence. The lead biker - named HOG - spea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's see, shall we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hog tips the satchel's contents out onto Carnegie's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOOKS. About a dozen different volumes of all shapes and sizes. Carnegie rifles excitedly through the collection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see various titles as he sorts through them. Treasure Island. The Da Vinci Code. A volume of encyclopedia. The Diary of Anne Frank. Tuesdays with Morrie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In amongst the books are a few MAGAZINES. An old issue of OPRAH magazine. A torn copy of SPORTS ILLUSTRATED...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And a NEWSWEEK. The cover graphic illustrates OPPOSING NUCLEAR ARSENALS over a world globe. On one side the STAR AND STRIPES, on the other flags indicating a SINO-ISLAMIC ALLIANCE. The headline reads: "IS THERE NO TURNING BACK?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No. No. No. No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Carnegie rejects each book with growing disappointment frustration, it's clear he's looking for a specific volum

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These ain't worth nothin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you bring me the book I asked you for, it'll be worth something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bikers exchange more looks. An unspoken conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We been doin' this a long time now. Had to make a whole lotta corpses to bring you all these books. You want us to keep at it, reckon it's worth more than a few free glasses of that swill you call liquor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie's guards bristle, ready for a confrontation. Carnegie just smiles, always ready to smooth things over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, gentlemen. I urge you once again to take the long view here. When we find this book - and believe me, we will find it - we are going to build a new world. A world far greater, far more righteous than this one. And you and I are going to be perched right on top of it, looking down upon it, masters of all creation!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As always, his carefully stage-managed rhetoric is delive with the utmost conviction, every word dripping with pass and persuasion. He's a master salesman, a true huckster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you know, I think you're absolutely right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARNEGIE (cont'd) That is worth more than a few glasses of liquor. A whole lot more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps forward and looks Hog right in the eye. His gaze like a laser beam, utterly disarming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The book I want is out there somewhere, just waiting to be found. Once there were millions of copies - you only need to find one! Find it and bring it here. And I promise you, you will be rewarded beyond anything you can imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's impossible not to be swayed by this guy. He's just s full of fiery passion and infectious belief, you almost w to reach into your pocket and hand over your wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hog snatches up his empty satchel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This better not be bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and marches to the door, the other bikers follow The guards escort them out, only Redridge remains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie slumps back into his chair, frustrated, pissed o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might help if they knew just what they were looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not one of them can read. How would they even know when they found it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how's about you just tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie and Redridge lock eyes. BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two years now you been sending these crews into the outland. Burning up gas we can barely spare. For a goddamn book? What the hell kinda book can be worth all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie ignores him. Stands, walks toward the door. Redr sighs, gestures toward the books piled on Carnegie's desk

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put them with the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redridge stands by the marble fireplace, tossing the book into the fire. The flames flicker and leap around the boo as their pages blacken and are consumed by the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli watches as the engineer charges the battery with the generator, which chugs noisily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He licks his lips, dry as sand. Unscrews his canteen to t a drink, but it's down to its last few drips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this place across the street? They got any water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got our own underground spring here. Only fresh water in a hundred miles - if's you can pay for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli thinks a while longer. Then stands and stuffs his sho inside his pack, shoulders his gear and makes for the doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli stops in the doorway and turns back to the engineer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that battery ain't here when I get back, I will use this gun on your kneecaps and I will put this building to the torch and I will watch it burn to the ground with you alive inside it. So help me God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that he turns and leaves. The engineer gulps. No hint in Eli's voice that he didn't mean every word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This old second-floor DRESSING ROOM has been converted in bedroom, simply furnished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WOMAN stands in front of an old DRESSING ROOM MIRROR, t bulbs around the frame burned-out and broken. She washes face in murky water in an old PORCELAIN BOWL on the dress

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her name is CLAUDIA. Early 30s, pretty. She gazes into th mirror as she dries her hands, but it's so cracked and wa it's near impossible to see a reflection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Carnegie enters. He still looks steame Claudia doesn't turn to look at him, keeps facing the mir

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that you, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie says nothing. Just paces angrily up and down. Finally Claudia turns to face him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More books came in from the road today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? It's been a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it'll be a while longer. Just another pile of useless junk. If we don't find the right one soon - if I can't give these people what they want to hear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie trails off, the thought too awful to contemplate Claudia adopts a sympathetic expression, supportive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll find what you're looking for. It's out there somewhere. You just have to have faith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This seems to anger Carnegie. He wheels on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faith? Is that what you think we're missing around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She detects the aggressive tone in his voice and goes qui head bowed. Carnegie moves toward her angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My old man used to have faith. He had it in spades. My mother, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARNEGIE (cont'd) You know where it got them? You know where it got me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in her face now. Claudia avoids eye contact, submiss

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faith is for the weak. It's for them out there, the sheep. This world is what you can see and touch and taste. It's what you make it. All these years with me, you still don't have any grasp of that? What's wrong with you, woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's shouting now, and she's trembling, afraid to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie realizes he's frightened her. He softens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm sorry. I didn't mean to scare you. Hey. You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts her chin up, wipes away a tear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just get me all riled up with that kind of talk. It's not what I need from you right now. (SMILES) You know what I need right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his hands on her lustfully. It's clear she's not the mood, but she halfheartedly responds anyway. More out a sense of wifely duty than reciprocated passion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they kiss, Carnegie pushes her excitedly against the w and feverishly begins unbuckling his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The original customers have now been joined by the four bikers, who sit at their own table drinking a clear and pungent moonshine-type liquor from a shared jar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli enters. All eyes are on him immediately, regarding hi with guarded interest as he pulls up a stool at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BARTENDER approaches, looks him up and down. Suspicio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outlander? Let me see-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli raises his hand as before. Holds it outstretched, ste

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'll it be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli places the canteen on the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the good stuff. Gotta eat into my own ration to sell it - so I don't sell it cheap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli takes off his scarf and puts it on the bar. The barte takes it and looks it over. Not particularly impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll get you maybe half-way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bartender spies Eli's silver Saint Christopher pendan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli stuffs the pendant inside his shirt. No way that's fo sale. Instead, he reaches into his coat and produces the pelts he skinned from the dead cat, lays them out on the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the best I got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bartender takes a pelt and examines it. The mangy cat leaps up onto the bar and approaches. Sniffs at the pelts with suspicion and HISSES at Eli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli shoos the cat off the bar with a wave of his hand. At biker's table Hog watches this, not happy about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Satisfied with the pelts, the bartender gathers them up a with the scarf, then turns away toward the back room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solara!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TEENAGE GIRL emerges from the back. No older than 16 or Dressed in unflattering work clothes, face grimy, blonde tied back in a ponytail. But even through all this, it's clear she is a strikingly beautiful young woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bartender takes Eli's canteen and hands it to Solara along with a RATION CARD he keeps around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take this out back and get it filled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solara takes the canteen, pausing for a moment to look El and down. Unsure quite what to make of him, but intrigued There's something about him she can't put her finger on..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't look back at her. She turns and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solara exits via the Palladium's STAGE DOOR and walks acr the busy street to where TWO OF CARNEGIE'S ARMED MEN stan guard around an ENCLOSURE OF CHAIN-LINK FENCE TOPPED WITH RAZOR WIRE. TOWNSFOLK wait in line with bowls and buckets

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the guards recognizes Solara and lets her cut to t front of the line. He punches two holes in her ration car and lets her inside the chain-link enclosure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside is an OLD RUSTED SPIGOT attached to a pipe emergin from the earth. Solara cranks hard on the handle - it tak few pulls before the water comes, and then only at a weak trickle; it will take a while to fill the canteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Eli sits at the bar, a SHADOW comes into view and loom large over him. Hog is standing behind him, glaring, cutt a menacing figure in his armored cycle leathers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solara senses trouble brewing and moves off, taking Eli's canteen away into the back room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was my cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli doesn't turn. Just looks straight ahead. Impossible t read him behind those mirrored goggles. Utterly inscrutab

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine specimen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you push him off the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't push him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You raised your hand at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. It won't happen again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bartender looks at Hog nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, how about another drink, Hog?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That cat's been comin' in here for nigh on two years. It got more right to be here than you. Who the fuck do you think you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want any trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hog grabs him by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's too bad, `cause-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blink. Suddenly Hog's head is pinned to the bar by nothin more than Eli's thumb. Pressed deep into a nerve cluster his neck. Eli leans in close as Hog whimpers, paralyzed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you. Murderer of innocent travelers on the road. You're going to spend eternity drowning in a lake of fire for the things that you've done. Did you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other bikers stand and approach, the OTHER CUSTOMERS following suit. Eli senses the trouble gathering behind h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go on back to your table and I'll be on my way. All right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all Hog can do to just barely nod his head. Eli rele his thumb. Hog staggers backward, gasping for breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli stands and makes toward the door, but the bikers and other patrons have moved to block his exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You push Hog, you push all of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli sighs, looks down at the floor. He's been pushed one too many today. For the first time, we see anger in his f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cursed be the ground because of you. By toil shall you eat of it. Thorns and thistles shall it sprout for you. From the ground were you taken. For dust you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The patrons look at Eli strangely. Who is this guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli reaches back and draws the samurai sword. Carves a li in the dirt at his feet with the tip of the blade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And to dust you shall return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie has Claudia pinned against the wall, his pants bunched around his ankles, ass bared as he pounds away at her. Not making love. This is mechanical, loveless sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claudia stares vacantly over his shoulder into space as Carnegie thrusts into her again and again. Deeply uninterested, just waiting for it to be over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, we hear a CRASH O.S. Carnegie stops and listens

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear that? What was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claudia sees an opening to get out of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you should go check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEAT. Carnegie keeps listening. Then comes another CRASH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in the hell is going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls up his pants, grabbing a RIFLE propped by the do as he rushes out. Claudia just stands there for a moment, then reaches down and pulls up her panties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves from the wall and makes her way across the room feeling her way with her hands, gazing off into nothingne Only now do we finally realize that she is BLIND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie emerges from the bedroom onto the balcony. Looks down over the railing - and is stunned by what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHAOS in the bar below. Eli cutting a one-man swath of ma through the dozen brawlers. Most already lie dead. TWO MO MEN ATTACK Eli and are effortlessly felled by his sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie rushes hurriedly along the landing, banging loud on the doors of the upstairs rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your asses out here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON ELI. Surrounded by the dead, only one man left standin Hog. He backs away as Eli circles him like a predator. Sw held ready, the blade glistening with dark red blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOLARA re-emerges from the back room with Eli's refilled canteen. She stops and emits a horrified GASP when she se the bloody carnage laid out in the bar before her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She watches, mortified, as Eli moves toward the helpless, terrified Hog, going in for the kill. Raising his sword..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Solara steps forward and CRIES OUT:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli FREEZES. Sword hanging in the air, poised to strike. turns his head to where Solara stands behind the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEAT as Eli considers. He looks back at Hog, still comple at his mercy... and then LOWERS THE SWORD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONFUSED) ...What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't for me to judge you. Your time for that's gonna come. Believe me. Now go on. Get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hog stumbles backward through the door, into the sunlight Eli moves toward Solara, who stands petrified behind the Reaches out and gently pries the canteen from her loose g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the exitway, Hog turns back inside, grabbing up a BROK BOTTLE from the bloody floor as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hog rushes Eli from behind. Solara sees him coming and go to SCREAM - but before any sound can come, Eli flips his sword backward and Hog runs right onto it, SKEWERING HIMS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEAT. Hog just stands there for a moment, eyes wide, froz in shock. His fingers go limp, dropping the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slides off the sword and collapses to the floor, dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli wipes the sword clean and sheathes it. Looks around a the bloodied, fallen bodies. Then back at Solara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry for all the mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he turns and heads toward the door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it right there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Accompanied by the sound of MULTIPLE GUNS COCKING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie is on the landing, training his rifle down at El Alongside him, FIVE GUNMEN do the same. They've got him c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie sits at his desk, the huge auditorium and stage visible behind him. Eli stands before him. Around him are other gunmen, who keep their weapons trained on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing at Carnegie's side are REDRIDGE and CLAUDIA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody. A walker in the outland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've met walkers before. Not a particularly civilized bunch. Some have even taken to eating their own kind, did you know that? You wouldn't be one of those savages now, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie's gunmen look him over, inspecting him warily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't got the shakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie's confident gaze remains fixed on Eli throughout

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. This is a civilized town. Under God. Do you know what that means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli can't help but react at the mention of that word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means we have laws here. Laws set down long before any of us ever walked this earth. And one of them is, you don't eat the flesh of your brother. Else you're no better than an animal. And not welcome here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli doesn't respond. Just stands there in Carnegie's gaze

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's your business here, friend? Walkers don't usually come into town less they want something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a battery needed charging and a canteen needed filling. I didn't come here looking for trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barely noticeable, Carnegie gestures to one of the gunmen who nods in acknowledgement and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you sure as hell found it. Do you know who I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Carnegie. I own this bar. I own the whole town. You've never heard of me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's you out there on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remarkable likeness, isn't it? You'd never guess half the men who built it were blind. A small tribute from a grateful people. I was deeply touched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had slaves build you a monument to yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mention of that word rankles Carnegie. He walks aroun the desk toward Eli, waves an admonishing finger at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't call them slaves. That's an old word. I'm not a slaver. I'm trying to help these people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnegie can't help himself - once again he is in his nat element, spinning the argument his way, pitching. Selling

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the outland the sightless are preyed upon like sick animals. Here at least they're protected. They do the essential work others don't want. And in return they eat, they drink, they survive. Last year, a couple of them even got married - performed the ceremony myself. (BEAT) You see, I'm not exploiting these people - I'm saving them! Any one of them is free to leave whenever they wish. But here they stay. And they thank me every single day for their salvation!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An impressive, impassioned performance. He sounds just li an old-school TV evangelist. But Eli is unmoved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's none of my business what you do here. Like you said, it's your town. I just want to be on my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name, walker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli doesn't respond. Just stands there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I guess we just call you Walker. Don't see too many folks your age these days. You lived in the world before? You can read?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARNEGIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good. Good man. We educated folk, we need to stick together, if we're ever going to rebuild this world. People like you and me, we're the future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARNEGIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straight to the point. I like that. Fact is, you could be in a lot of trouble. This is a peaceful town. You walk in here, armed, and the next thing a dozen of my good citizens are dead. I've hanged men for less. I could hang you. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or, you could come work for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARNEGIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never once saw anyone handle themselves the way you did down there in that bar. I don't know where you learned it, but I sure as hell could use it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARNEGIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People who work for me can live better than any walker ever dreamed. Real beds, clean water, hot food. Women, even. You could do a lot worse, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not your friend. And I'm not staying. I got someplace I need to be. Out west.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARNEGIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: West? There is nothing west. It's all gone, a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been told different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli doesn't reply. Carnegie smiles, dials up the charm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, look. I'm going to make you an offer of goodwill. Stay the night, think it over. Try a little local hospitality. We'll talk again in the morning. If you're still not interested, you're free to go. No hard feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for your offer. But I'd prefer to just leave right now. So you can either let me out of here, or I can kill my way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gunmen bristle, exchange nervous looks. Carnegie appe unfazed. He smiles. BEAT. He looks to the gunman at the d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gunman opens the door. Eli turns and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The engineer stands behind the counter, looking worried. heart sinks when he sees Eli enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's my battery?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's, uh... it's gonna take a little longer than I thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much longer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gotta charge overnight. You, uh, you can always stay here in town, pick it up in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli leans in a little closer. He smells a rat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember what I said would happen if I came back here and you didn't have my battery?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's right here! It's just gonna take a while longer. I swear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli looks at the engineer. Hard to be certain, but he's pretty sure he's lying. Somebody got to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A VIOLENT COMMOTION is heard from down the hall. Suddenly of Carnegie's henchmen comes flying into view as he is TH HARD INTO A WALL and slumps to the floor, unconscious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli storms into the box, pissed. MORE GUARDS rush in behi him. Carnegie, seated behind his desk, waves the guards o as he stands to greet Eli, smiling ingratiatingly as ever

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you'd reconsider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? How'd you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of the walkers I've seen come here from the outland were ever what you'd call smart. I mean all those years out there alone on the road, some with their brains half- fried from eating each other - it's understandable why you people aren't the brightest bulbs in the box. But I never met one so dumb that he'd turn down a meal and a bed if it was offered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you didn't send someone across the street to the engineer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Engineer? I don't know what you're talking about. If there's something wrong, maybe I can help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
